questions.question: Which of the following acts as the primary trigger for the onset of labor in pregnant women?
questions.explanation: The fetal ACTH causes an increase in estrogen, acting as the onset of labor in pregnant women. It results in the growth of the fetal adrenal gland, which has the capacity for steroid biosynthesis, i.e., estrogen. Daily steroid production of fetal adrenal glands near term is more than in adults. Physiology of parturition: Hypothalamus CRH Positive feedback Anterior pituitary ACTH Adrenal gland Baby Cortisol DHEA Placental CRH PGE2 PGF2a Estradiol-17β Estriol Hypothalamus Posterior pituitary Oxytocin ↑ receptors for oxytocin and PGs † gap junctions in myometrium Rupture of membranes + ↑ contractions Labour Placenta Mother

questions.question: All of the following changes are seen during cervical ripening in a patient except
questions.explanation: Collagen fibrils are loosely packed during cervical ripening. Changes in cervical ripening: • Collagen fibril diameter is increased, and there is increased spacing between fibrils leading to increased tissue compliance • Increase in the amount of proteoglycan and glycosaminoglycan within the matrix • Stromal invasion with inflammatory cells

questions.question: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. What is the reflex elicited in the process?
questions.explanation: Stripping of membranes is depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex. Fetal ejection reflex or Ferguson reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary has been suggested but not proven. It is seen in stripping/sweeping and artificial rupture of membranes. Both of these are methods of induction of labor. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost/carboprost.

questions.question: Which of the following images shows the Duncan method?
questions.explanation: Image B shows the Duncan method of placental separation. Schultze method, Mathews-Duncan method, Brandt Andrew's method, Type III Placenta Previa. Comparison between two types of placental separation methods: Brandt Andrew's method or controlled cord traction is a manoeuvre of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labour. One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fingers over the anterior surface of the uterus. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backwards and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord. Type III placenta previa is a type of incomplete or partial central placenta previa. Here, the placenta covers the internal os partially, i.e., it covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated. Schultze method: Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Duncan method: Separation begins from the periphery to the center. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

questions.question: In which stage of labour is the following expelled?
questions.explanation: The placenta and membranes are expelled in the third stage of labour. The clinical stages of labour may be summarized as follows: Stages of labour - First: True labour pain to full dilatation of cervix, Second: Full dilatation of cervix to expulsion of fetus, Third: Expulsion of fetus to expulsion of placenta, Fourth: One hour observation after the expulsion of placenta.

questions.question: All of the following are included in the first stage of labour for a pregnant woman except:
questions.explanation: The encirclement of the largest head diameter by the vulval ring is called crowning. This occurs in the second stage of labour. First stage of labour is divided into 2 phases: Latent phase - The onset of true labour pain up to 6cm cervical dilatation. Duration: 10-12 hours - nullipara, 6-8 hours - multipara. Mainly cervical effacement occurs. Active phase - From 6cm cervical dilatation with regular uterine contractions. Rate of cervical dilatation: 1.2cm/hr - nullipara, 1.5 cm/hr - multipara. Mainly cervical dilatation occurs.

questions.question: What does fetal position refer to? Part of presentation which lies over the internal os. b) Relation of different parts of fetus to one another. c) Relation of the denominator to different quadrants of the pelvis. d) Part of fetus lying in the lower segment of uterus. Question 8: A senior resident examines a primigravida in labour and informs that the fetus is cephalic in attitude of flexion. What is the most common presenting part of this fetus?
questions.explanation: Fetal position refers to the bony fixed point of reference on the presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis. Definition of various terminologies used for fetus in-utero: Term: Lie Definition: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine. Term: Presentation Presenting part Attitude Denominator Position Engagement Definition: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis. Part of the presentation which overlies the internal os. The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another. An arbitrary bony fixed point on the presenting part which comes in relation with the various quadrants of the maternal pelvis. Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis. When the biparietal diameter has passed the plane of the pelvic brim, the head is said to be engaged.

questions.question: The ultrasonogram shows the diameter of the fetal head which is taken as a reference forengagement. Which diameter does this refer to?
questions.explanation: The fetal head is said to be engaged when the biparietal diameter (shown in the image) passesthrough the pelvic brim. Engagement of fetal head is with reference to this biparietal diameter.It is the greatest transverse diameter in an occiput presentation. It also reflects the gestational agein the second trimester, with a variation of 7-10 days.BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septumpellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inneredge of the skull in the far field.IliaccrestStation of the head is in relation toischial spines-5--43Ischial spine--10+1Ischial tuberosity+3+4+5-cmPerineumOMARROWFloatingEngagedCrowning192

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of a partograph?
questions.explanation: Fetal temperature is not a part of a partograph.Assessment of progress of labor is best done by partograph. Components of partograph:• Patient identification•• Fetal heart rate recorded every 30 min• Pulse recorded every 30 min• Blood pressure and temperature recorded every 4 h• Uterine contractions recorded every 30 min••Oxytocin-dose and concentration• Urine analysis• Vaginal examination done every 4 hours.• State of membranes and colour of liquor

questions.question: What are the cardinal movements of labour?
questions.explanation: The cardinal movements of labour are engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension,external rotation, expulsion.(Mnemonic: Every Day FIRE Raises Extremely)••• Every: Engagement• Day: Descent• F: Flexion• IR: Internal rotation⚫ E: Extension•• Raises: external Rotation•Extremely: ExpulsionThe most common presentation is cephalic and presenting part is vertex. Head enters the pelvisthrough transverse diameter majorly and left occipito transverse is the commonest fetal position.Internal rotation of fetal head occurs at the level of ischial spine. In a vertex delivery, the baby'shead is delivered by extension and in a breech delivery, the baby's head is delivered by flexion.The best time to give episotomy is after crowning has occured.193Cardinal movements of labor and deliveryfrom a loft occiput anterior position.Head floating, beforeEngagement,desoent,engagement,Further desocnt, internalrotation.Complete extensionDelivery of anteriorshoulder(C) MARROWVCompleterotation,beginning of extension.Restitution(external rotation)Delivery Orshoulder

questions.question: A multigravida with gestational diabetes mellitus was admitted in labour at term andprogressed to full dilatation. The fetal vertex failed to descend beyond -3 station. The descentof the fetus is facilitated by all except:

options.A: Extension and straightening of the fetal body

questions.explanation: A well-flexed head facilitates internal rotation, not the descent of the presenting part.The descent of the fetus is brought about by:• Pressure of amniotic fluid• Direct pressure of the fundus upon the breech with contractions• Bearing-down efforts of maternal abdominal muscles•Extension and straightening of the fetal body

questions.question: Which of the following is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the fetal head for a woman inlabor?
questions.explanation: The tone of levator ani muscles is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the head.Prerequisites of internal rotation of the head are as follows:•• Well-flexed head• Efficient uterine contraction•Favorable shape at mid-pelvic plane.• Tone of the levator ani muscles

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the internal rotation of the fetal head?181

options.A: Occiput turns towards the transverse axis
options.B: Rotation is not essential when the fetus is unusually small
options.C: Internal rotation is followed by external rotation
options.D: Rotation is earlier in primigravida than in multigravida

questions.explanation: Internal rotation is not essential in the completion of labor when the fetus is unusually small.194Internal rotation begins with the occiput turning away from the transverse axis. Inmajority, internal rotation is completed by the time the head reaches the pelvic floor. Internalrotation is followed by extension of the head, which is then followed by external rotation.Rotation occurs earlier in multigravida than primigravida whereas engagement occurs earlier inprimigravida than multigravida.

questions.question: What is the minimum rate of cervical dilatation in primigravida during active labour?
questions.explanation: During active labor, the minimal rate of cervical dilatation in primigravida is 1.2 cm/hr.First stage of labour is divided into 2 phases:The cervical dilatation ranges from a minimal rate of 1.2 cm - 6.8 cm/hr in nullipara. Also, themultiparas progress faster in the active phase of labor with a minimal dilatation rate of 1.5 cm/hr.Friedman curve is the sigmoid curve plotting the pattern of cervical dilatation during the latentand active phase of normal labour.Latent phaseThe onset of true labor painup to 6 cm cervical dilatationActive phaseStarts from ≥ 6 cm cervical dilatation with regular uterinecontractionsDuration:12 h (nullipara)8 h ( The minimum rate of cervicalmultipara)Concerned with cervicaleffacementdilatation:1.2 cm/h (nullipara)1.5 cm/h (multipara)Concerned with cervicaldilatation102Cervical Dilation, cm•00Accel.PhaseMARREANPhaseof max.slopeDecel.PhaseSec.phaseLatent phase026Time, hrOMARROWActive phase8101214195

questions.question: Which of the following is part of the WHO guidelines for the management of second stage oflabor?

options.B: Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
options.C: Never give warm compress to the perineum

questions.explanation: The practice of guarding the perineum during delivery of the fetal head is part of the WHOmanagement guidelines for the second stage of labor.The fingers of one hand support the perineum, while the second hand applies pressure to the fetalhead to control the speed of crowning. The advantage of this is to prevent perineal tears.The second stage of labor begins with full dilatation of the cervix and ends with the delivery of thefetus.The main events include the descent of the fetus (bearing down by the mother, uterinecontractions), cardinal movements of labor, and delivery of the fetus.Management of the second stage of labor:• The most common position used is the dorsal position with the hips flexed, knees flexed andabduction of the thighs. WHO recommends any position of choice including the upright position.• WHO recommendations for the prevention of perineal tears include warm compresses to theperineum, perineal massage, guarding the perineum, and modified Ritgen's maneuver.• Modified Ritgen's maneuver: A sterile towel or pad is held in one hand and placed over theperineum; the other hand applies gentle downward pressure on the occiput to promote flexionand controlled delivery of the head (ensuring the smallest diameter of the head passes through theoutlet). Once the occiput is born-with gentle pressure, the head is extended-forehead, nose, andmouth are then delivered.• WHO doesn't recommend fundal pressure and routine episiotomy.Other options:Option A: A liberal or routine episiotomy is discouraged. Episiotomy is indicated in cases of:•Shoulder dystocia•Breech delivery• Fetal macrosomia•Operative vaginal deliveries• Persistent occiput posterior positionsOption C: Manual techniques, such as massage or application of warm compresses, arerecommended for healthy pregnant women requesting pain relief during labor.Option D: The position that is most comfortable to the mother i.e. upright/squatting position isencouraged. This position gives:••less discomfort and difficulty in bearing down• less labor pain• less perineal/vaginal trauma and wound infectionsSecond stageMean/average durationMaximum durationNulliparous50 minutesMultiparous30 minutes2 hours (+1 with epidural)1 hour (+1 with epidural)196Second stageWHO maximum duration of2nd stage/diagnosis of arrestNulliparous3 hoursMultiparous2 hours

questions.question: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes:

options.C: Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
options.D: Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.explanation: Class 1 of modified Robson's classification includes nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single,cephalic, spontaneous labor.It is the most widely accepted classification system available for analyzing characteristics ofdelivering women worldwide. It consists of 10 patient population categories. The basis for thesecategories include:• Parity• Onset of labor and mode of delivery• Gestational age•• Fetal presentation• No. of fetusesThe modified Robson system classification is as follows:Class1Class2Class3Class4Class5Class6Class7Class8Nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, spontaneous laborNullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic2a:induced labor2b:CS before laborMultipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, spontaneous labor (excludes previousCS)Multipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic4a:induced labor4b:CS before laborMultipara, previous CS, equa1 to or >37 weeks, single, cephalicNullipara, single, breechMultipara, single, breech (including previous CS)Multiple pregnancies (with orwithout previous CS)197Class1Class9Class10Nullipara, equal to or >37 weeks, single, cephalic, spontaneous laborSingleton pregnancy, oblique/transverse lie (with or without previous CS)Single, cephalic <37 weeks (including previous CS)

questions.question: Identify the fetal position in the given image.182
questions.explanation: In the given vertex presentation, the fetal position is right occipitoanterior.Fetal position refers to the relation of the denominator (arbitrary bony fixed point on thepresenting part), with respect to different quadrants of the maternal pelvis. In vertex presentation,the denominator is taken as the occiput (which is close to the triangular posterior fontanelle).To determine the fetal position the following two steps are followed:•Determine the direction in which the occiput is facing:• Towards the pubic symphysis -occipito-anterior•Towards the sacral promontory - occipito-posterior•Midway between pubic symphysis and sacral promontory - occipito-transverse• Determine if the occiput is facing the left or the right in relation to the materal pelvisThe position and relative frequency ofthe vertex at the onset of laborPosteriorOccipitoposterior1%Right OccipitoPosterior7%RightOccipitoTransverse24%RightRight OccipitoAnterior10%Occipito AnteriorAnteriorMARROWleft OccipitoPosterior3%LeftOccipitoTransverse40%Left OccipitoAnterior13%Left

questions.question: Uterine contractions are palpable when its intensity is more than
questions.explanation: Uterine contractions are palpable when the intensity is >10 mmHg.198Uterine contractions cause cervical dilatation at 15 mmHg and are painful beyond 15 mmHg.Units for measuring the intensity of uterine contractions are mmHg and Montevideo units (MV).1 MV = intensity of uterine contractions x number of contractions in 10 min.During labour, normal uterine contractions are between 190 and 300 MV and at the time ofdelivery, it is 300 MV.Stage of labouPressurer1st2nd40-50 mmHg100-120mmHg3rd100-120mmHg

questions.question: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 39 weeks of gestation. On examination, younotice the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can beused to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.explanation: Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open thevaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used toexert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exertspressure superiorly against the occiput.This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.question: Which dermatome is pain in the early stage of labor limited to?
questions.explanation: Ritgen's maneuverOMARROW199Pain in the early stage of labor is limited to dermatomes T10-L1. This is of uterine origin.Pain in the late stage of labour is due to dilatation of cervix and perineal stretching. The nervescarrying the pain include S2,3,4.

questions.question: A young primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presented to the casualty crying of intenseabdominal pain. She was diagnosed to be in labour. Which of the following is not acharacteristic of this pain?
questions.explanation: True labor pain is not relieved by enema and sedatives.It is characterized by the following:• Painful uterine contractions at regular intervals•⚫ The frequency of contractions increases gradually• The intensity and duration of contractions increase progressively• Associated with 'show'- extrusion of the mucus plug that had previously filled the cervical canalduring pregnancy• Progressive effacement and dilatation of the cervix•Progressive descent of the presenting partFormation of the 'bag of forewaters' i.e., bulging fluid-filled amniotic membrane presenting infront of the fetal head• Not relieved by enema or sedativesFalse labour pain is seen more in primigravidae than in parous women. It usually appears prior tothe onset of true labor pain by 1 or 2 weeks in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae.Such pains are probably due to stretching of the cervix and lower uterine segment withconsequent irritation of the neighboring ganglia.FeaturesTrue labour painsFalse labour painCervical dilatation and effacementPresentAbsentPainLower abdomen and back, radiating to thighsLower abdomenonlyShowPresentAbsentBag of waterFormedAbsentRelief with enemaNoYes

questions.question: You notice the gynecology resident administer the nerve block seen in the image beforeperforming an episiotomy. Which nerve roots are blocked?OMARROW184Ischialtuberosity-IschialspineSacrospinousligament
questions.explanation: The nerve roots blocked in pudendal nerve block are S2,3,4. It is blocked just above the tip ofthe ischial spine by piercing the sacrospinous ligament.200Pudendal nerve block can be used for:• Analgesia in the second stage of labor•Episiotomy repair• Pelvic floor relaxation for outlet instrument delivery• Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum• Perineal analgesia prior to application of vacuum/forcepsPudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina. It is ineffective for pain reliefassociated with uterine manipulation such as manual extraction of the placenta.

questions.question: Paracervical block relieves pain from all except:
questions.explanation: Pain from the lower third of the vagina is relieved by pudendal block, not paracervical block.Paracervical block relieves the pain of uterine contractions and cervical dilatation. It also relievespain from upper third of the vagina. It is not useful at the time of episiotomy as the lower part ofthe vagina is not anesthetized.Note: Paracervical block is no longer considered safe as it causes fetal bradycardia. Epiduralanalgesia is preferred when complete relief of pain is needed throughout labour.

questions.question: All of the following are indications for early clamping of cord in a new born baby except:
questions.explanation: Postdated pregnancy is not an indication for early cord clamping.Early cord clamping is indicated in:• Birth asphyxia• Rh isoimmunization• Diabetic motherThe benefits of delayed cord clamping for up to 60 seconds is an increase in total body iron stores,expand blood volume and a decrease in anemia incidence in the neonate.On the other hand, delayed cord clamping can lead to a higher hemoglobin concentration, whichincreases risks for hyperbilirubinemia and extended hospitalization for neonatal phototherapy.Delayed cord clamping can also hinder timely neonatal resuscitation.According to AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology, in uncomplicated preterm birth, delayed cordclamping should be attempted. This is done for a minimum time of 60 seconds after delivery forpreterm infants not requiring immediate resuscitation after birth. It states that DCC must be doneeven if the mother has an HIV infection. But as per the NACO guidelines, early cord clamping isadvised.201

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of placental separation in stage 3 of parturition of apregnant woman?
questions.explanation: Lengthening of the umbilical cord is seen in placental separation.Signs of placental separation:•⚫ The uterus becomes globular, firm, and ballottable (earliest sign to appear)•Schroeder's sign - Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lowersegment and uterus rests over it•⚫ Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.•Kustner's sign - On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord nolonger recedes• A sudden gush of blood•Permanent lengthening of cordNote: Schroeder's ring is a constriction ring/contraction ring formed due to incoordinate uterineaction.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding the modified WHO partogram?185

options.A: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
options.B: Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
options.C: Each small square in partogram is equal to 1 hour
options.D: Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.explanation: Each small square in a modified WHO partogram is equal to 30 minutes. Each small square ina composite WHO partogram is equal to 1 hour.

questions.question: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics.
questions.explanation: The instrument given in the picture is episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is toprevent the extension of pelvic tears into the anal margins and obstetric anal sphincter injuries /complete perineal tears.Complications of episiotomy:They can be immediate or remote.Immediate complications include an extension of the incision into the rectum, vulval hematoma,wound dehiscence and injury to anal sphincter.Remote complications include dyspareunia, chances of perineal lacerations in subsequent laborand scar endometriosis (rare).Mayo scissors are long and stout scissors. They can be blunt-tipped/pointed tip/straight or curved.Straight mayo scissors are designed for cutting body tissues near the surface of a wound. They arealso used to cut sutures and are also known as suture-cutting scissors.Curved mayo scissors allow much deeper penetration into the wound and are used to cut thicktissues such as those found in the uterus, muscles, breast, and foot. Mayo scissors used fordissection are placed in tissue with the tips closed. The scissors are then opened so that the tipsopen and spread out the tissue during the dissection process.202Episiotomy scissorOMARROWNormal Mayo scissorsOMARROW

questions.question: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to monitor the progress oflabour. After how much dilatation of the cervix, should she start the documentation?
questions.explanation: The WHO Labour Care Guide begins the documentation of labour progression at 5 cm of cervicaldilatation.The WHO Labour Care Guide is a tool designed to help health personnel involved in labour care.It aims to• Guide the monitoring and help in the documentation of the progress of labour.Guide the health professionals to offer supportive care throughout labour.• Assist doctors in promptly identifying and addressing emerging labour complications..•Prevent the use of unnecessary interventions in labour.•Support audits and quality improvement.203The differences between the WHO-modified partograph and the latest WHO Labour Care Guideare tabulated below:Note: Previously the answer to the question was 4 cm (according to the modified WHOpatograph). However, this information is outdated, therefore the answer to this question has beenrevised per the latest WHO guidelines.WHO modified partographDocumentation of labour progression begins at4 cmof cervical dilatation.Fixed1 cm/hour ‘alert' and 'action'linesMonitoring of labour is restricted to thefirst stageonly.No section on supportive care interventionsDocumentation ofstrength, duration, and frequencyof uterine contractionsWHO Labour Care GuideDocumentation of labour progression begins at5 cmof cervical dilatation.Time-based cut-offsforeach centimetreof cervical dilatation to guide the obstetrician totake action. For example, at 5cm of cervical dilatation, if there is no progress >6 hours,action needs to be taken.Monitoring ofthe second stage of labouris includedAddition of a section onsupportive careof the mother- labour companionship, pain relief, oral fluid intake and postureDocumentation ofonlytheduration and frequency of uterine contractionsSHARED DECISION-MAKINGMEDICATIONLABOUR PROGRESSWOMANBABYNameRuptured membranes [DateTimeHoursALERTCompanionN"Pain reliefNOral fluidNPostureBaseline10, 2160FHRFHRdecelerationFetal positionCaputMouldingLAmniotic fluidM+++, BPT++++++Pulse<60, 2120<80, 140Systolic BPDiastolic BPTemperature "CUrine29035.037.5P++A++per 10 minDuration ofcontractions12,>5<20, >60109≥2hCervix2.5h[Plot x]x3h6=5h5= 6h54Descent3[Plot O]1Oxytocin (WL, drops/min)Medicinerv fluksASSESSMENTPLANParityTime1 Risk factorsWHO LABOUR CARE GUIDELabour onsetACTIVE FIRST STAGEActive labour diagnosis [Date1012SECOND STAGE-In active first stage, plot 'X' torecord cervical dilatation. Alerttriggered when lag time forcurrent cervical dilatation isexceeded with no progress. Insecond stage, Insert P to indicatewhen pushing begins.INITIALSINSTRUCTIONS: CIRCLE ANY OBSERVATION MEETING THE CRITERIA IN THE "ALERS COLUNK, ALERT THE SENIOR MIDWIFE OF DOCTOR AND RECORD THE ASSESSMENT AND ACTION TAKEN IF LABOUR EXTENDS BEYOND 12H, PLEASE CONTINUE ON A NEW LABOUR CAFE GUIDEAbbreviation: Y-Yes, N-No, D-Dedined, U-USP-Suping MO-ME-Eaty, L-Late, V-Vartable,-Intact C-Class M-Mac, B-Blood, A-Ararior, -Pastor T-Transvena, P+ Protein A-ActorWorld Health Organizado, 2021.Soma righe saved Liana (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0).
